content.text: Once upon a time, in a kingdom nestled between rolling green hills and a whispering forest, there lived an old king who had three sons.
The eldest was strong and proud, the second was clever and quick-witted, and the youngest—well, the youngest was called Simpleton, for he was gentle and kind but not as quick as his brothers.
The king, who was growing frail with age, knew it was time to choose an heir to his throne.
But how? He loved all his sons, and each had his own strengths.
One evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon and painted the sky in hues of gold and pink, the king called his sons to his chamber.
The fire crackled in the hearth, casting long shadows on the stone walls.
"My dear sons," he said, his voice steady but weary, "the time has come for me to decide who shall rule this kingdom after I am gone.
But I do not wish to choose unfairly.
So, I have devised a test—one that will reveal who among you is most worthy."  The eldest son puffed out his chest, certain of his victory.
The second son stroked his chin, already plotting his strategy. Simpleton, however, simply listened, his eyes wide with curiosity.
The king reached into his cloak and pulled out three feathers—one golden, one silver, and one plain white.
He held them up for all to see. "These feathers shall guide you," he said.
"I will blow them into the air, and wherever each feather lands, that is where you must go.
The one who returns with the most extraordinary treasure shall be crowned king."  The princes nodded, though Simpleton’s brothers exchanged skeptical glances.
The king then blew the feathers into the air.
The golden feather soared high and landed far to the east, near the mountains.
The silver feather drifted gracefully and settled to the west, by the sparkling river.
The plain white feather, however, barely lifted from the king’s hand before fluttering straight down to the floor at Simpleton’s feet.
The eldest son laughed.
"A fine treasure I shall find in the mountains!" he declared, striding off without a backward glance.
The second son smirked. "And I shall uncover riches by the river!" he said, hurrying after his brother.
Simpleton, however, knelt down and picked up the white feather.
It felt soft in his hand, like a whisper of wind.
He looked up at his father, who gave him an encouraging nod. "Go on, my son," the king said.
"Follow where the feather leads."  Simpleton stepped out of the castle and into the moonlit night.
The white feather lay still in his palm, pointing toward a narrow path that wound into the heart of the whispering forest.
With a deep breath, he followed it, his footsteps quiet on the damp earth.
The trees loomed tall around him, their leaves rustling secrets in the breeze.
After some time, the path opened into a small clearing, where a great toad sat upon a mossy stone.
The toad blinked its golden eyes and croaked, "Good evening, young prince.
What brings you to my humble glade?"  Simpleton bowed politely. "I seek a treasure, good toad.
My father, the king, has sent me to find the most extraordinary one."  The toad chuckled, a sound like bubbles popping in a pond.
"Ah, then you are in luck!
I have just the thing." It hopped down from the stone and waddled over to a small, round door set into the base of an ancient oak.
With a flick of its webbed foot, the door creaked open, revealing a tiny staircase descending into the earth.
"Follow me," the toad said, and Simpleton, though curious, did as he was told.
The staircase spiraled downward until they reached a cozy chamber lit by glowing mushrooms.
In the center of the room stood a small wooden chest.
The toad nudged it open with its nose, and inside lay a single, shimmering carpet—so fine it seemed woven from moonlight itself.
"This is no ordinary carpet," the toad explained.
"It is a flying carpet, and it will take you wherever you wish to go.
But be warned—it only obeys the kindest of hearts."  Simpleton’s eyes widened with wonder.
"Thank you, good toad!" he exclaimed.
He carefully lifted the carpet, rolled it up, and tucked it under his arm.
Then, with a grateful bow, he climbed back up the staircase and returned to the forest path.
Meanwhile, the eldest prince had reached the mountains.
He climbed and climbed until his hands were raw and his breath came in gasps.
At last, he found a cave where a great dragon guarded a hoard of gold and jewels.
The dragon’s eyes gleamed like embers as it hissed, "Who dares disturb my treasure?"  The eldest prince, though strong, trembled.
"I—I am the king’s son," he stammered.
"I seek a treasure to prove my worth."  The dragon laughed, a sound like thunder. "Very well.
Take this gold, but know that greed will be your undoing." The prince filled his sack with as much treasure as he could carry and hurried back to the castle, his heart pounding with excitement.
The second prince, meanwhile, had reached the river.
There, he found a fisherman’s hut where an old woman sat spinning thread.
She looked up as he approached and smiled. "Ah, a prince!
What brings you to my humble home?"  "I seek a treasure," the second prince said, his voice smooth.
"Something to prove I am the worthiest to rule."  The old woman nodded.
"I have just the thing." She reached into her apron and pulled out a small, silver mirror.
"This mirror shows not your reflection, but the truth of any person you wish to see.
But beware—it only reveals what is already in your heart."  The second prince took the mirror, his eyes gleaming with ambition.
"Thank you, good woman!" He tucked it into his cloak and set off for the castle, already imagining how he might use it to outwit his brothers.
When all three princes returned to the castle, the king sat upon his throne, his hands folded in his lap.
The eldest prince stepped forward first, dumping his sack of gold and jewels at the king’s feet. "Behold, Father!
The greatest treasure in the land!"  The king examined the riches, then turned to the second prince, who held up the silver mirror.
"And I have brought this, Father.
With it, I can see the truth of any man—or prince!"  The king nodded thoughtfully, then looked at Simpleton, who stood quietly at the back of the hall, the rolled-up carpet still under his arm.
"And what have you brought, my son?"  Simpleton unrolled the carpet, and it shimmered in the torchlight.
"I have brought this, Father.
It is a flying carpet, given to me by a kind toad in the forest.
It will take me wherever I wish to go."  The eldest prince scoffed. "A carpet?
What use is that compared to gold and jewels?"  The second prince smirked.
"Or a mirror that reveals the truth?"  But the king’s eyes softened as he looked at Simpleton.
"Tell me, my son—why did the toad give you this carpet?"  Simpleton thought for a moment.
"Because it said the carpet only obeys the kindest of hearts.
And—and I think it knew I would not use it for greed or trickery, but for good."  The king smiled.
"Then it is settled.

The most extraordinary treasure is not gold, nor a mirror, but a gift given to the one who is pure of heart." He turned to his court and announced, "Simpleton shall be the next king, for he has proven himself wise in ways his brothers have not."  The eldest prince’s face darkened with anger.
"But Father, I brought you riches!"  The second prince crossed his arms.
"And I brought you the power of truth!"  The king shook his head.
"Gold can be stolen, and truth can be twisted.
But kindness and humility—those are the true treasures of a ruler." He placed his hand on Simpleton’s shoulder.
"You shall rule with a gentle heart, and our kingdom will prosper."  And so, Simpleton became king, and he ruled with wisdom and kindness.
The flying carpet became a symbol of his reign, used to bring joy and aid to his people.
The eldest prince learned the value of humility, and the second prince discovered that truth without kindness is hollow.
And as for the old king?
He lived out his days in peace, knowing he had chosen the right heir.

And if you listen closely on a quiet night, when the wind rustles through the trees, you might just hear the whisper of the three feathers—gold, silver, and white—carrying the lesson that the greatest treasures are not always the ones we expect.
